user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_SetDeferredRetcode:
```c
void UT_SetDeferredRetcode(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, int32 Count, UT_IntReturn_t Retcode)
{
    /* The count should always be a positive integer, if not there is a bug in the test */
    if (Count <= 0)
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("BUG: Invalid Count (%ld) passed to UT_SetDeferredRetcode()", (long)Count);
    }
    else
    {
        UT_ConfigureGenericStubReturnValue(FuncKey, &Retcode, sizeof(Retcode), UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, Count, NULL);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
void UT_SetDeferredRetcode(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, int32 Count, UT_IntReturn_t Retcode)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment: the function does not assign to or otherwise modify its parameters. Taking the address of the value parameter ( &Retcode ) and passing it to another function does not itself modify the parameter. However, a possible violation scenario would be if UT_ConfigureGenericStubReturnValue were to write to the memory pointed to by that pointer (i.e., modify *(&Retcode)), because that would modify the parameter variable Retcode and thus violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. To avoid that potential violation, pass a local non-parameter object or ensure the callee only reads the pointed-to data.
